titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to Special Collections in the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2005

change.item: Editorial revisions made to this finding aid by Nancy Seeger in March 2010.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The collection includes Heifetz's personal music library of original compositions, arrangements, and transcriptions (some of which are unpublished), his annotated parts and scores, holographs and manuscripts of many of his contemporaries, and hundreds of printed scores. Concert programs document his performances from 1911 to 1974, and photographs, photo albums, and scrapbooks, encompassing the violinist's entire life. The correspondence, constituting a small part of the collection, contains letters from such important musical figures of the 20th century as Leopold Auer, Benjamin Britten, Sergei Prokofiev, George Bernard Shaw, and Sir William Walton; correspondence from Heifetz is also housed in other Music Division collections.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Jascha Heifetz Collection was processed in 1998 by Mark Eden Horowitz and Mark Katz. This Finding Aid was prepared with Corel WordPerfect 8. In 2003, Michael A. Ferrando coded and edited the finding aid for EAD format.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings were transferred to the Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Some books were transferred to the Library of Congress general Music Division collections.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright on the materials of the Jascha Heifetz Collection is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

userestrict.head: Restrictions
userestrict.p: The Jascha Heifetz Collection is open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Performing Arts Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: container number, Jascha Heifetz Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: First violin lessons with father, Ruvim (Reuven)
Admitted to St. Petersburg Conservatory; begins studies with Leopold Auer
Berlin Philharmonic debut under Arthur Nikisch, performing Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto
Makes first recordings, for Victor records
Tours Far East; purchases Guarneri del Gesu violin
Tours Russia for the first and last time after immigrating to the United States
Stars in Samuel Goldwyn film "They Shall Have Music"
Premieres concerto by William Walton in Cleveland under Artur Rodzinski
Performs at American military bases, completing three overseas tours for USO campshows
Takes two-year sabbatical from concert performance; continues to record
Joseph (Jay) born to Frances and Jascha Heifetz
Deposits collection of music and correspondence at the Library of Congress
Attacked following Jerusalem recital, apparently for having performed the Richard Strauss violin sonata
Forms duo with cellist Gregor Piatigorsky
Begins teaching at the University of Southern California
"Heifetz Collection," a 5-volume 30-disc set, released by RCA

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Jascha Heifetz Collection, in the breadth and variety of its contents, gives a rare and comprehensive look at the life of one of history's most important violinists. Heifetz's personal music library includes his original compositions, arrangements and transcriptions (some of which are unpublished), his annotated parts and scores, holographs and manuscripts of many of his contemporaries, and hundreds of printed scores (at least some of which appear to have been previously owned by Joseph Achron). Concert programs document his performances from 1911 to 1974, and photographs, photo albums, and scrapbooks, encompassing the violinist's entire life, capture Heifetz in performance, with his family, and with notable personalities. And the correspondence, constituting a small part of the collection, contains letters from such important musical figures of the twentieth-century as Leopold Auer, Benjamin Britten, Sergei Prokofiev, George Bernard Shaw, and Sir William Walton.
The Music has been further divided into four subseries:

In using the guide to the Music, the following distinctions should be observed. Bracketed titles are uniform titles, assigned in accordance with Anglo-American Cataloguing Rules, second edition. Non-bracketed titles are shown as they appear on the music itself. Numbers in parentheses refer to the number of copies. Where no contrary information is give, music may be assumed to be printed. All of Heifetz's compositions, with the exception of the cadenzas and Theme and Variations, were published under the pseudonym of Jim Hoyl.
The rest of the materials in the collection are divided into five series:

There are approximately 2,000 items in the Programs subseries. The majority of these are concert and recital programs dating from Heifetz's 1917 Carnegie Hall debut to his last concerts in 1974. The remainder consists of programs of Heifetz's radio appearances (and often the scripts for these shows), program files, and a program notebook. The program files, arranged alphabetically by performance location (city or country), although headings also exist under "Radio" and "Repertoire," contain typescript concert and recital programs as well as typescript and manuscript repertoire lists. The program notebook lists programs of receitals given by Heifetz in the United States and Canada between 1930 and 1956; these programs are arranged alphabetically by city. The researcher using the Programs subseries should further note that encores are often listed in the program files and in the program notebook, and that duplicate and additional Heifetz programs can be found in the scrapbooks in the Jascha Heifetz Collection and in the general collections of the Music Division.

The items in the Correspondence subseries are arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Except where noted, letters are to Heifetz. A few letters are kept with musical scores, but are cross-referenced in the Correspondence subseries.

The scrapbooks and photograph albums have been left intact. Size, rather than date order, was used as the organizing principal for these items, as many of them contain unusually large date spans that frequently overlap. Although an attempt has been made to provide date ranges under the titles (where they occur) of the scrapbooks, these are not to be considered definitive because so much material is either undated or in foreign languages.

Books from Mr. Heifetz's library have been treated in several different ways. The books of particular significance, due to inscriptions, annotations, etc., have been kept with the collection and are listed under Appendix I. Books that became part of the general collection of the Library of Congress are listed in Appendix II. Books that were returned to the Jascha Heifetz Estate are listed in Appendix III.
The sound recording transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound division are listed here in Appendix IV.
Mark Katz and Mark Horowitz, January 1998

arrangement.head: Organization of the Jascha Heifetz Collection
arrangement.p: The Jascha Heifetz Collection is organized into six series:

scopecontent.p: Heifetz's personal music library includes his original compositions, arrangements and transcriptions (some of which are unpublished), his annotated parts and scores, holographs and manuscripts of many of his contemporaries, and hundreds of printed scores (at least some of which appear to have been previously owned by Joseph Achron).

arrangement.p: The Music series has been divided into four subseries:

list.item: Music Arranged and Edited by Jascha Heifetz

arrangement.p: In using the guide to the Music, the following distinctions should be observed. Bracketed titles are uniform titles, assigned in accordance with Anglo-American Cataloguing Rules, second edition. Non-bracketed titles are shown as they appear on the music itself. Numbers in parentheses refer to the number of copies. Where no contrary information is give, music may be assumed to be printed. All of Heifetz's compositions, with the exception of the cadenzas and Theme and Variations, were published under the pseudonym of Jim Hoyl.

did.unittitle: Index card file of Heifetz's library

scopecontent.p: The Programs series contains concert programs of his performances from 1911 to 1974.

arrangement.p: The Programs series are arranged alphabetically by performance location (city or country).

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series contains letters from such important musical figures of the twentieth-century as Leopold Auer, Benjamin Britten, Sergei Prokofiev, George Bernard Shaw, and Sir William Walton.
The Photographs series contains photographs of Heifetz as well as other prints.

arrangement.p: The Photographs series are organized by size, rather than date order, as many of them contain unusually large date spans that frequently overlap.
The Scrapbooks series are organized by size, rather than date order, as many of them contain unusually large date spans that frequently overlap.

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous series consists of Artwork, Honorariums, Posters and other miscellaneous items.
